//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The domain controller is named client-a.lab.local, it’s can’t be A. D is correctly stating the label name but the connection is from the firewall to the user-ID agent which make the wording bad but it is the best answer.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A because the user-id agent is on the firewall. It's polling the DC and it's connected.

Selected Answer: A

https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClRyCAK

lab-client = AD server, connected is showing the agent is connect to this AD server....

I, for some reason, was thinking this is a local user-id agent. However, you can see the Kerberos information.
this is on the exam

I dont think any of these options are correct:
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-web-interface-help/user-identification/device-user-identification-user-mapping/monitor-servers/configure-access-to-monitored-servers

A. should say it's connected to "lab.client" So this is wrong:
B. The User ID agent is the firewall, as this is using Client Probing. So the firewall is the agent. The AD server is lab.client. So this is wrong
C. Is the closest but again, "host" to me means the DC. Hosting of the user-id information. So this is wrong.
D. Again, the firewall is the user-id agent here. The part showing connected is the User-id agent(the firewall) connected to the DC. So this is wrong...

not sure what they are wanting.

comments.content: that sums up lots of questions on this test...
A seems to be fine, the controller is called/labeled as lab-client, which is the name we define when configuring PA-integrated User-ID Agent.

discussion.content: It looks like A is correct. This is the PA Integrated User-ID Agent (not the Windows UIA). In the Server Monitoring section, we configure the name of the server/controller to which the firewall will connect. In this case, the firewall UIA connects to AD called 'lab-client'.

Selected Answer: A
I think its A.
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/user-id/user-id-concepts/user-mapping/server-monitoring

Selected Answer: D
I will go with D

choices.C: The host lab-client has been found by a domain controller.
choices.B: The host lab-client has been found by the User-ID agent.
choices.A: The User-ID agent is connected to a domain controller labeled lab-client.
choices.D: The User-ID agent is connected to the firewall labeled lab-client.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
options:Forward , Discard , no PBF

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C. See doc:

Set the Action to take when matching a packet:
Forward—Directs the packet to the specified Egress Interface.
Forward to VSYS (On a firewall enabled for multiple virtual systems)—Select the virtual system to which to forward the packet.
Discard—Drops the packet.
No PBF—Excludes packets that match the criteria for source, destination, application, or service defined in the rule. Matching packets use the route table instead of PBF; the firewall uses the route table to exclude the matched traffic from the redirected port.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-admin/policy/policy-based-forwarding/create-a-policy-based-forwarding-rule#ideca3cc65-03d7-449d-b47a-90fabee5293c
Answer C is correct: Forward, Dicard, and No PBF are valid options.

Selected Answer: C
C - Discard

Set the Action to take when matching a packet:
Forward—Directs the packet to the specified Egress Interface.
Forward to VSYS (On a firewall enabled for multiple virtual systems)—Select the virtual system to which to forward the packet.
Discard—Drops the packet.
No PBF—Excludes packets that match the criteria for source, destination, application, or service defined in the rule. Matching packets use the route table instead of PBF; the firewall uses the route table to exclude the matched traffic from the redirected port.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/policy/policy-based-forwarding/create-a-policy-based-forwarding-rule#ideca3cc65-03d7-449d-b47a-90fabee5293c

questions.question_text: What can be used as an Action when creating a Policy-Based Forwarding (PBF) policy?

An engineer manages a high availability network and requires fast failover of the routing protocols. The engineer decides to implement BFD.

Which three dynamic routing protocols support BFD? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
"In addition to BFD for static routes, the firewall supports BFD for the BGP, OSPF, and RIP routing protocols."

"The firewall does not support BFD on an OSPF or OSPFv3 virtual link."

IGRP is a Cisco-proprietary protocol that is not mentioned in the Palo Alto Networks documentation.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-networking-admin/bfd/bfd-overview/bfd-for-dynamic-routing-protocols

Selected Answer: ADE
A, D and E correct

Correct: ADE
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-networking-admin/bfd/bfd-overview/bfd-for-dynamic-routing-protocols

Selected Answer: ADE
That is the correct answer

Correct is ADE 
In addition to BFD for static routes, the firewall supports BFD for the BGP, OSPF, and RIP routing protocols.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-networking-admin/bfd/bfd-overview/bfd-for-dynamic-routing-protocols

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is valid.

Selected Answer: A
THATS the correct answer for me

Selected Answer: A
A: because the question is for the firewall commit response time, not Pano
For Panorama
Disabling Share Unused Address and Service Objects with Devices might increase the commit time on Panorama because Panorama has to 
dynamically check whether policy rules reference all the particular objects.
For PA-220
On lower-end models, such as the PA-220, consider pushing only the relevant shared objects to the managed firewalls. 
This is because the number of objects that can be stored on the lower-end models is considerably lower than that of the mid- to high-end models. 
>https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/panorama/9-1/panorama-admin/manage-firewalls/manage-device-groups/manage-unused-shared-objects

Selected Answer: A
I see other's saying it may make the Panorama commit take longer. Remember, on a Commit and Push, the candidate config is being pushed to both the Panorama and the Firewall(s). The question indicates the PA220 commit is taking longer. On the Panorama Administrator's guide, it says the Panorama commit can take longer when clearing "Share Unused Address and Service Objects with Devices." However, right before that it says, "if you have many address and service objects that are unused, clearing Share Unused Address and Service Objects with Devices reduces the commit times significantly on the firewalls because the configuration pushed to each firewall is smaller."
I don't see a correct answer at all. A would be correct if you said to enable that option, so I'm going with this question was input incorrectly.

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/panorama/9-1/panorama-admin/manage-firewalls/manage-device-groups/manage-unused-shared-objects

Selected Answer: A
I think A is correct. 

https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000Cm1CCAS

comments.content:
On lower-end models, such as the PA-220, consider pushing only the relevant shared objects to the managed firewalls. This is because the number of objects that can be stored on the lower-end models is considerably lower than that of the mid- to high-end models. Also, if you have many address and service objects that are unused, clearing Share Unused Address and Service Objects with Devices REDUCES the commit times significantly ON THE FIREWALLS because the configuration pushed to each firewall is smaller. However, disabling this option might INCREASE the commit time ON PANORAMA because Panorama has to dynamically check whether policy rules reference a particular object.
Since the question is based around the 220's being too slow, the Answer is A.

Your own link says this increases the commit time: Disabling Share Unused Address and Service Objects with Devices might increase the commit time on Panorama because Panorama has to dynamically check whether policy rules reference all the particular objects.

questions.question_text:
A company has recently migrated their branch office’s PA-220s to a centralized Panorama. This Panorama manages a number of PA-7000 Series and PA-5200 Series devices. All device group and template configuration is managed solely within Panorama.

They notice that commit times have drastically increased for the PA-220s after the migration.

What can they do to reduce commit times?

choices.D: Use “export or push device config bundle” to ensure that the firewall is integrated with the Panorama config.
choices.B: Perform a device group push using the “merge with device candidate config” option.
choices.A: Disable “Share Unused Address and Service Objects with Devices” in Panorama Settings.
choices.C: Update the apps and threat version using device-deployment.

questions.question_text:
An administrator is troubleshooting why video traffic is not being properly classified.

If this traffic does not match any QoS classes, what default class is assigned?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct is D 

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/quality-of-service/qos-concepts/qos-classes

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-admin/quality-of-service/qos-concepts/qos-classes

A QoS class determines the priority and bandwidth for traffic matching a QoS Policy rule. You can use a QoS Profile to define QoS classes. There are up to eight definable QoS classes in a single QoS profile. Unless otherwise configured, traffic that does not match a QoS class is assigned a class of 4.

"D" is correct.
There are up to eight definable QoS classes in a single QoS profile. Unless otherwise configured, traffic that does not match a QoS class is assigned a class of 4.

Selected Answer: D
default class is 4
